learning_outcomes.description: Design a simple experiment complying with the required accuracy of the measurements.
Apply statistical methods to data analysis.
Apply a number of commonly used experimental techniques including modern based-on-computer technologies.
Write professional scientific reports and use laboratory notebooks to keep clear records and protect intellectual property.
Work independently on an extended, open-ended project.

assessments.weighting: <dd>25% First 3 modules: Logbook (10%) Written report (65%); Oral discussion (25%). Last module: Logbook (20%) Written report (80%);  </dd>
assessments.due_date:
The logbook must be presented to a member of the teaching staff at the end of each lab session and is marked on a pass/fail basis.

The written report for each module is due every 3 weeks, one week after the completion of the lab work for that module. The order of modules varies for each student.

An in-person discussion (up to 10 minutes) is conducted with a staff member for the first three modules. This takes place in the week following the week when the report is submitted. During the discussion, students are expected to explain their experimental results and answer questions. They may refer to their logbook and written report.
assessments.task_description:
Each module contributes 25% to the final grade.

For the first three modules, the assessment is based on three components:

  1. Logbook (10%)
  2. Written report (65%)
  3. Oral discussion (25%)


The fourth module does not include an in-person oral discussion. Instead, the assessment is based on:

  1. Logbook (20%)
  2. Written report (80%)


  • Each student must submit a written report and a logbook for each module. The logbook should contain records of laboratory activities, including raw data, observations, notes on the experimental procedures and phenomena, a sketch of experimental setup, etc. The final report which comprises description of the experiment, experimental data, data analysis, conclusion.
  • For the first three modules, assessment includes an in-person discussion (typically up to 10 minutes) with a staff member. During this discussion, students are expected to explain the results of their experiment and respond to questions. They may refer to their logbook and written report while answering.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Report should be submitted electronically (as a PDF file) through the link in Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Hands-on activity

The following activities will be scheduled during the semester. A specific timetable will be determined for each student and depends on the enrolment and availability of facilities at the Centre of Microscopy and Microanalysis (CMM) and Australian National Fabrication Facility (ANFF-Q)

Module 1: Microfabrication and Advanced Imaging
- Electron microscopy and other super resolution (down to atomic level) imaging techniques
- Micro-fabrication (photolithography)

Module 2: Advanced Spectroscopy
- Raman Spectroscopy
- High resolution Diode Spectroscopy

Module 3: Computer Control and Electronics
- Basic of Electronics
- LabView

Module 4: Quantum Technology
- Superconducting Quantum Interference Device (SQUID)
- HeNe laser


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
